segment.source: Assemble the rendering framework
segment.target: Assemble the rendering framework

segment.source: Now, it's time to look at how the sample game uses that structure and state to display its graphics.
segment.target: Now, it's time to look at how the sample game uses that structure and state to display its graphics.

segment.source: Assemble the rendering framework
segment.target: Assemble the rendering framework

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: By now, you've seen how to structure a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game to work with the Windows Runtime, and how to define a state machine to handle the flow of the game.
segment.target: By now, you've seen how to structure a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game to work with the Windows Runtime, and how to define a state machine to handle the flow of the game.

segment.source: Now, it's time to look at how the sample game uses that structure and state to display its graphics.
segment.target: Now, it's time to look at how the sample game uses that structure and state to display its graphics.

segment.source: Here, we look at how to implement a rendering framework, starting from the initialization of the graphics device through the presentation of the graphics objects for display.
segment.target: Here, we look at how to implement a rendering framework, starting from the initialization of the graphics device through the presentation of the graphics objects for display.

segment.source: Objective
segment.target: Objective

segment.source: To understand how to set up a basic rendering framework to display the graphics output for a UWP DirectX game.
segment.target: To understand how to set up a basic rendering framework to display the graphics output for a UWP DirectX game.

segment.source: Note The following code files are not discussed here, but provide classes and methods referred to in this topic and are provided as code at the end of this topic:
segment.target: Note The following code files are not discussed here, but provide classes and methods referred to in this topic and are provided as code at the end of this topic:

segment.source: Animate.h/.cpp.
segment.target: Animate.h/.cpp.

segment.source: BasicLoader.h/.cpp.
segment.target: BasicLoader.h/.cpp.

segment.source: Provides methods for loading meshes, shaders and textures, both synchronously and asynchronously.
segment.target: Provides methods for loading meshes, shaders and textures, both synchronously and asynchronously.

segment.source: Very useful!
segment.target: Very useful!

segment.source: MeshObject.h/.cpp, SphereMesh.h/.cpp, CylinderMesh.h/.cpp, FaceMesh.h/.cpp, and WorldMesh.h/.cpp.
segment.target: MeshObject.h/.cpp, SphereMesh.h/.cpp, CylinderMesh.h/.cpp, FaceMesh.h/.cpp, and WorldMesh.h/.cpp.

segment.source: Contains the definitions of the object primitives used in the game, such as the ammo spheres, the cylinder and cone obstacles, and the walls of the shooting gallery.
segment.target: Contains the definitions of the object primitives used in the game, such as the ammo spheres, the cylinder and cone obstacles, and the walls of the shooting gallery.

segment.source: (GameObject.cpp, briefly discussed in this topic, contains the method for rendering these primitives.)
segment.target: (GameObject.cpp, briefly discussed in this topic, contains the method for rendering these primitives.)

segment.source: Level.h/.cpp and Level\[1-6\].h/.cpp.
segment.target: Level.h/.cpp and Level\[1-6\].h/.cpp.

segment.source: Contains the configuration for each of the games six levels, including the success criteria and the number and position of the targets and obstacles.
segment.target: Contains the configuration for each of the games six levels, including the success criteria and the number and position of the targets and obstacles.

segment.source: TargetTexture.h/.cpp.
segment.target: TargetTexture.h/.cpp.

segment.source: Contains a set of methods for drawing the bitmaps used as the textures on the targets.
segment.target: Contains a set of methods for drawing the bitmaps used as the textures on the targets.

segment.source: These files contain code that is not specific to UWP DirectX games.
segment.target: These files contain code that is not specific to UWP DirectX games.

segment.source: But you can review them separately if you'd like more implementation details.
segment.target: But you can review them separately if you'd like more implementation details.

segment.source: This section covers three key files from the game sample (provided as code at the end of this topic):
segment.target: This section covers three key files from the game sample (provided as code at the end of this topic):

segment.source: Camera.h/.cpp
segment.target: Camera.h/.cpp

segment.source: GameRenderer.h/.cpp
segment.target: GameRenderer.h/.cpp

segment.source: PrimObject.h/.cpp
segment.target: PrimObject.h/.cpp

segment.source: Again, we assume that you understand basic 3D programming concepts like meshes, vertices, and textures.
segment.target: Again, we assume that you understand basic 3D programming concepts like meshes, vertices, and textures.

segment.source: For more info about Direct3D 11 programming in general, see Programming Guide for Direct3D 11.
segment.target: For more info about Direct3D 11 programming in general, see Programming Guide for Direct3D 11.

segment.source: With that said, let's look at the work that must be done to put our game on the screen.
segment.target: With that said, let's look at the work that must be done to put our game on the screen.

segment.source: An overview of the Windows Runtime and DirectX
segment.target: An overview of the Windows Runtime and DirectX

segment.source: DirectX is a fundamental part of the Windows Runtime and of the Windows 10 experience.
segment.target: DirectX is a fundamental part of the Windows Runtime and of the Windows 10 experience.

segment.source: All of Windows 10's visuals are built on top of DirectX, and you have the same direct line to the same low-level graphics interface, DXGI, which provides an abstraction layer for the graphics hardware and its drivers.
segment.target: All of Windows 10's visuals are built on top of DirectX, and you have the same direct line to the same low-level graphics interface, DXGI, which provides an abstraction layer for the graphics hardware and its drivers.

segment.source: All the Direct3D 11 APIs are available for you to talk to DXGI directly.
segment.target: All the Direct3D 11 APIs are available for you to talk to DXGI directly.

segment.source: The result is fast, high performing graphics in your games that give you access to all the latest graphics hardware features.
segment.target: The result is fast, high performing graphics in your games that give you access to all the latest graphics hardware features.

segment.source: To add DirectX support to a UWP app, you create a view provider for DirectX resources by implementing the IFrameworkViewSource and IFrameworkView interfaces.
segment.target: To add DirectX support to a UWP app, you create a view provider for DirectX resources by implementing the IFrameworkViewSource and IFrameworkView interfaces.

segment.source: These provide a factory pattern for your view provider type and the implementation of your DirectX view provider, respectively.
segment.target: These provide a factory pattern for your view provider type and the implementation of your DirectX view provider, respectively.

segment.source: The UWP singleton, represented by the CoreApplication object, runs this implementation.
segment.target: The UWP singleton, represented by the CoreApplication object, runs this implementation.

segment.source: In Defining the game's UWP framework, we looked at how the renderer fit into the game sample's app framework.
segment.target: In Defining the game's UWP framework, we looked at how the renderer fit into the game sample's app framework.

segment.source: Now, let's look at how the game renderer connects to the view and builds the graphics that define the look of the game.
segment.target: Now, let's look at how the game renderer connects to the view and builds the graphics that define the look of the game.

segment.source: Defining the renderer
segment.target: Defining the renderer

segment.source: The GameRenderer abstract type inherits from the DirectXBase renderer type, adds support for stereo 3-D, and declares constant buffers and resources for the shaders that create and define our graphic primitives.
segment.target: The GameRenderer abstract type inherits from the DirectXBase renderer type, adds support for stereo 3-D, and declares constant buffers and resources for the shaders that create and define our graphic primitives.

segment.source: Here's the definition of GameRenderer.
segment.target: Here's the definition of GameRenderer.

segment.source: Because the Direct3D 11 APIs are defined as COM APIs, you must provide ComPtr references to the objects defined by these APIs.
segment.target: Because the Direct3D 11 APIs are defined as COM APIs, you must provide ComPtr references to the objects defined by these APIs.

segment.source: These objects are automatically freed when their last reference goes out of scope when the app terminates.
segment.target: These objects are automatically freed when their last reference goes out of scope when the app terminates.

segment.source: The game sample declares 4 specific constant buffers:
segment.target: The game sample declares 4 specific constant buffers:

segment.source: m\_constantBufferNeverChanges.
segment.target: m\_constantBufferNeverChanges.

segment.source: This constant buffer contains the lighting parameters.
segment.target: This constant buffer contains the lighting parameters.

segment.source: It's set one time and never changes again.
segment.target: It's set one time and never changes again.

segment.source: m\_constantBufferChangeOnResize.
segment.target: m\_constantBufferChangeOnResize.

segment.source: This constant buffer contains the projection matrix.
segment.target: This constant buffer contains the projection matrix.

segment.source: The projection matrix is dependent on the size and aspect ratio of the window.
segment.target: The projection matrix is dependent on the size and aspect ratio of the window.

segment.source: It's updated only when the window size changes.
segment.target: It's updated only when the window size changes.

segment.source: m\_constantBufferChangesEveryFrame.
segment.target: m\_constantBufferChangesEveryFrame.

segment.source: This constant buffer contains the view matrix.
segment.target: This constant buffer contains the view matrix.

segment.source: This matrix is dependent on the camera position and look direction (the normal to the projection) and changes only one time per frame.
segment.target: This matrix is dependent on the camera position and look direction (the normal to the projection) and changes only one time per frame.

segment.source: m\_constantBufferChangesEveryPrim.
segment.target: m\_constantBufferChangesEveryPrim.

segment.source: This constant buffer contains the model matrix and material properties of each primitive.
segment.target: This constant buffer contains the model matrix and material properties of each primitive.

segment.source: The model matrix transforms vertices from local coordinates into world coordinates.
segment.target: The model matrix transforms vertices from local coordinates into world coordinates.

segment.source: These constants are specific to each primitive and are updated for every draw call.
segment.target: These constants are specific to each primitive and are updated for every draw call.

segment.source: The whole idea of multiple constant buffers with different frequencies is to reduce the amount of data that must be sent to the GPU per frame.
segment.target: The whole idea of multiple constant buffers with different frequencies is to reduce the amount of data that must be sent to the GPU per frame.

segment.source: Therefore, the sample separates constants into different buffers based on the frequency that they must be updated.
segment.target: Therefore, the sample separates constants into different buffers based on the frequency that they must be updated.

segment.source: This is a best practice for Direct3D programming.
segment.target: This is a best practice for Direct3D programming.

segment.source: The renderer contains the shader objects that compute our primitives and textures: m\_vertexShader and m\_pixelShader.
segment.target: The renderer contains the shader objects that compute our primitives and textures: m\_vertexShader and m\_pixelShader.

segment.source: The vertex shader processes the primitives and the basic lighting, and the pixel shader (sometimes called a fragment shader) processes the textures and any per-pixel effects.
segment.target: The vertex shader processes the primitives and the basic lighting, and the pixel shader (sometimes called a fragment shader) processes the textures and any per-pixel effects.

segment.source: There are two versions of these shaders (regular and flat) for rendering different primitives.
segment.target: There are two versions of these shaders (regular and flat) for rendering different primitives.

segment.source: The flat versions are much simpler and don't do specular highlights or any per pixel lighting effects.
segment.target: The flat versions are much simpler and don't do specular highlights or any per pixel lighting effects.

segment.source: These are used for the walls and make rendering faster on lower powered devices.
segment.target: These are used for the walls and make rendering faster on lower powered devices.

segment.source: The renderer class contains the DirectWrite and Direct2D resources used for the overlay and the Heads Up Display (the GameHud object).
segment.target: The renderer class contains the DirectWrite and Direct2D resources used for the overlay and the Heads Up Display (the GameHud object).

segment.source: The overlay and HUD are drawn on top of the render target when projection is complete in the graphics pipeline.
segment.target: The overlay and HUD are drawn on top of the render target when projection is complete in the graphics pipeline.

segment.source: The renderer also defines the shader resource objects that hold the textures for the primitives.
segment.target: The renderer also defines the shader resource objects that hold the textures for the primitives.

segment.source: Some of these textures are pre-defined (DDS textures for the walls and floor of the world as well as the ammo spheres).
segment.target: Some of these textures are pre-defined (DDS textures for the walls and floor of the world as well as the ammo spheres).

segment.source: Now, it's time to see how this object is created!
segment.target: Now, it's time to see how this object is created!

segment.source: Initializing the renderer
segment.target: Initializing the renderer

segment.source: The sample game calls this Initialize method as part of the CoreApplication initialization sequence in App::SetWindow.
segment.target: The sample game calls this Initialize method as part of the CoreApplication initialization sequence in App::SetWindow.

segment.source: This is a pretty straightforward method.
segment.target: This is a pretty straightforward method.

segment.source: It checks to see if the renderer had been previously initialized, and if it hasn't, it instantiates the GameHud and GameInfoOverlay objects.
segment.target: It checks to see if the renderer had been previously initialized, and if it hasn't, it instantiates the GameHud and GameInfoOverlay objects.

segment.source: After that, the renderer initialization process runs the base implementation of Initialize provided on the DirectXBase class it inherited from.
segment.target: After that, the renderer initialization process runs the base implementation of Initialize provided on the DirectXBase class it inherited from.

segment.source: When the DirectXBase initialization completes, the GameInfoOverlay object is initialized.
segment.target: When the DirectXBase initialization completes, the GameInfoOverlay object is initialized.

segment.source: After initialization is complete, it's time to look at the methods for creating and loading the graphics resources for the game.
segment.target: After initialization is complete, it's time to look at the methods for creating and loading the graphics resources for the game.

segment.source: Creating and loading DirectX graphics resources
segment.target: Creating and loading DirectX graphics resources

segment.source: The first order of business in any game is to establish a connection to our graphics interface, create the resources we need to draw the graphics, and then set up a render target into which we can draw those graphics.
segment.target: The first order of business in any game is to establish a connection to our graphics interface, create the resources we need to draw the graphics, and then set up a render target into which we can draw those graphics.

segment.source: In the game sample (and in the Microsoft Visual StudioDirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template), this process is implemented with three methods:
segment.target: In the game sample (and in the Microsoft Visual StudioDirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template), this process is implemented with three methods:

segment.source: CreateDeviceIndependentResources
segment.target: CreateDeviceIndependentResources

segment.source: CreateDeviceResources
segment.target: CreateDeviceResources

segment.source: CreateWindowSizeDependentResources
segment.target: CreateWindowSizeDependentResources

segment.source: Now, in the game sample, we override two of these methods (CreateDeviceIndependentResources and CreateDeviceResources) provided on the DirectXBase class implemented in the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template.
segment.target: Now, in the game sample, we override two of these methods (CreateDeviceIndependentResources and CreateDeviceResources) provided on the DirectXBase class implemented in the DirectX 11 App (Universal Windows) template.

segment.source: For each of these override methods, we first call the DirectXBase implementations they override, and then add more implementation details specific to the game sample.
segment.target: For each of these override methods, we first call the DirectXBase implementations they override, and then add more implementation details specific to the game sample.

segment.source: Be aware that the DirectXBase class implementation included with the game sample has been modified from the version provided in the Visual Studio template to include stereoscopic view support and includes pre-rotation of the SwapBuffer object.
segment.target: Be aware that the DirectXBase class implementation included with the game sample has been modified from the version provided in the Visual Studio template to include stereoscopic view support and includes pre-rotation of the SwapBuffer object.

segment.source: CreateWindowSizeDependentResources is not overridden by the GameRenderer object.
segment.target: CreateWindowSizeDependentResources is not overridden by the GameRenderer object.

segment.source: We use the implementation of it provided in the DirectXBase class.
segment.target: We use the implementation of it provided in the DirectXBase class.

segment.source: For more info about the DirectXBase base implementations of these methods, see How to set up your UWP DirectX app to display a view.
segment.target: For more info about the DirectXBase base implementations of these methods, see How to set up your UWP DirectX app to display a view.

segment.source: The first of these overridden methods, CreateDeviceIndependentResources, calls the GameHud::CreateDeviceIndependentResources method to create the DirectWrite text resources that use the Segoe UI font, which is the font used by most UWP apps.
segment.target: The first of these overridden methods, CreateDeviceIndependentResources, calls the GameHud::CreateDeviceIndependentResources method to create the DirectWrite text resources that use the Segoe UI font, which is the font used by most UWP apps.

segment.source: CreateDeviceIndependentResources
segment.target: CreateDeviceIndependentResources

segment.source: The sample uses four text formatters: two for title header and title body text, and two for body text.
segment.target: The sample uses four text formatters: two for title header and title body text, and two for body text.

segment.source: This is used in much of the overlay text.
segment.target: This is used in much of the overlay text.

segment.source: The second method, CreateDeviceResources, loads the specific resources for the game that will be computed on the graphics device.
segment.target: The second method, CreateDeviceResources, loads the specific resources for the game that will be computed on the graphics device.

segment.source: Let's look at the code for this method.
segment.target: Let's look at the code for this method.

segment.source: CreateDeviceResources
segment.target: CreateDeviceResources

segment.source: In this example, in normal execution, the CreateDeviceResources method just calls the base class method and then calls the GameHud::CreateDeviceResources method (also listed previously).
segment.target: In this example, in normal execution, the CreateDeviceResources method just calls the base class method and then calls the GameHud::CreateDeviceResources method (also listed previously).

segment.source: If there's a problem later with the underlying graphics device, it might have to be re-initialized.
segment.target: If there's a problem later with the underlying graphics device, it might have to be re-initialized.

segment.source: In this case, the CreateDeviceResources method initiates a set of async tasks to create the game device resources.
segment.target: In this case, the CreateDeviceResources method initiates a set of async tasks to create the game device resources.

segment.source: This is done through a sequence of two methods: a call to CreateDeviceResourcesAsync, and then, when it completes, FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources.
segment.target: This is done through a sequence of two methods: a call to CreateDeviceResourcesAsync, and then, when it completes, FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources.

segment.source: CreateGameDeviceResourcesAsync and FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources
segment.target: CreateGameDeviceResourcesAsync and FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources

segment.source: CreateDeviceResourcesAsync is a method that runs as a separate set of async tasks to load the game resources.
segment.target: CreateDeviceResourcesAsync is a method that runs as a separate set of async tasks to load the game resources.

segment.source: Because it's expected to run on a separate thread, it only has access to the Direct3D 11 device methods (those defined on ID3D11Device) and not the device context methods (the methods defined on ID3D11DeviceContext), so it has the option to not perform any rendering.
segment.target: Because it's expected to run on a separate thread, it only has access to the Direct3D 11 device methods (those defined on ID3D11Device) and not the device context methods (the methods defined on ID3D11DeviceContext), so it has the option to not perform any rendering.

segment.source: The FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources method runs on the main thread and does have access to the Direct3D 11 device context methods.
segment.target: The FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources method runs on the main thread and does have access to the Direct3D 11 device context methods.

segment.source: The sequence of events for loading the game devices resources proceeds as follows.
segment.target: The sequence of events for loading the game devices resources proceeds as follows.

segment.source: CreateDeviceResourcesAsync first initializes constant buffers for the primitives.
segment.target: CreateDeviceResourcesAsync first initializes constant buffers for the primitives.

segment.source: Constant buffers are low-latency, fixed-width buffers that hold the data that a shader uses during shader execution.
segment.target: Constant buffers are low-latency, fixed-width buffers that hold the data that a shader uses during shader execution.

segment.source: (Think of these buffers as passing data to the shader that is constant over the execution of the particular draw call.) In this sample, the buffers contain the data that the shaders will use to:
segment.target: (Think of these buffers as passing data to the shader that is constant over the execution of the particular draw call.) In this sample, the buffers contain the data that the shaders will use to:

segment.source: Place the light sources and set their color when the renderer initializes
segment.target: Place the light sources and set their color when the renderer initializes

segment.source: Compute the view matrix whenever the window is resized
segment.target: Compute the view matrix whenever the window is resized

segment.source: Compute the projection matrix for every frame update
segment.target: Compute the projection matrix for every frame update

segment.source: Compute the transformations of the primitives on every render update
segment.target: Compute the transformations of the primitives on every render update

segment.source: The constants receive the source information (vertices) and transform the vertex coordinates and data from model space into the device space.
segment.target: The constants receive the source information (vertices) and transform the vertex coordinates and data from model space into the device space.

segment.source: Ultimately, this data results in texel coordinates and pixels in the render target.
segment.target: Ultimately, this data results in texel coordinates and pixels in the render target.

segment.source: Next, the game renderer object creates a loader for the shaders that will perform the computation.
segment.target: Next, the game renderer object creates a loader for the shaders that will perform the computation.

segment.source: (See BasicLoader.cpp in the sample for the specific implementation.)
segment.target: (See BasicLoader.cpp in the sample for the specific implementation.)

segment.source: Then, CreateDeviceResourcesAsync initiates async tasks for loading all the texture resources into ShaderResourceViews.
segment.target: Then, CreateDeviceResourcesAsync initiates async tasks for loading all the texture resources into ShaderResourceViews.

segment.source: These texture resources are stored in the DirectDraw Surface (DDS) textures that came with the sample.
segment.target: These texture resources are stored in the DirectDraw Surface (DDS) textures that came with the sample.

segment.source: DDS textures are a lossy texture format that work with DirectX Texture Compression (DXTC).
segment.target: DDS textures are a lossy texture format that work with DirectX Texture Compression (DXTC).

segment.source: We use these textures on the walls, ceiling and floor of the world, and on the ammo spheres and pillar obstacles.
segment.target: We use these textures on the walls, ceiling and floor of the world, and on the ammo spheres and pillar obstacles.

segment.source: Finally, it returns a task group that contains all the async tasks created by the method.
segment.target: Finally, it returns a task group that contains all the async tasks created by the method.

segment.source: The calling function waits for the completion of all these async tasks, and then calls FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources.
segment.target: The calling function waits for the completion of all these async tasks, and then calls FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources.

segment.source: FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources loads the initial data into the constant buffers with a device context method call to ID3D11DeviceContext::UpdateSubresource: .
segment.target: FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources loads the initial data into the constant buffers with a device context method call to ID3D11DeviceContext::UpdateSubresource: .

segment.source: This method creates the mesh objects for the sphere, cylinder, face, and world game objects and the associated materials.
segment.target: This method creates the mesh objects for the sphere, cylinder, face, and world game objects and the associated materials.

segment.source: It then walks the game object list associating the appropriate device resources with each object.
segment.target: It then walks the game object list associating the appropriate device resources with each object.

segment.source: The textures for the ringed and numbered target objects are procedurally generated using the code in TargetTexture.cpp.
segment.target: The textures for the ringed and numbered target objects are procedurally generated using the code in TargetTexture.cpp.

segment.source: The renderer creates an instance of the TargetTexture type, which creates the bitmap texture for the target objects in the game when we call the TargetTexture::CreateTextureResourceView method.
segment.target: The renderer creates an instance of the TargetTexture type, which creates the bitmap texture for the target objects in the game when we call the TargetTexture::CreateTextureResourceView method.

segment.source: The resulting texture is composed of concentric colored rings, with a numeric value on the top.
segment.target: The resulting texture is composed of concentric colored rings, with a numeric value on the top.

segment.source: These generated resources are associated with the appropriate target game objects.
segment.target: These generated resources are associated with the appropriate target game objects.

segment.source: Lastly, FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources set the Boolean global variable to indicate that all resources are now loaded.
segment.target: Lastly, FinalizeCreateGameDeviceResources set the Boolean global variable to indicate that all resources are now loaded.

segment.source: The game has the resources to display the graphics in the current window, and it can recreate those resources as the window changes.
segment.target: The game has the resources to display the graphics in the current window, and it can recreate those resources as the window changes.

segment.source: Now, let's look at the camera used to define the player's view of the scene in that window.
segment.target: Now, let's look at the camera used to define the player's view of the scene in that window.

segment.source: Implementing the camera object
segment.target: Implementing the camera object

segment.source: The game has the code in place to update the world in its own coordinate system (sometimes called the world space or scene space).
segment.target: The game has the code in place to update the world in its own coordinate system (sometimes called the world space or scene space).

segment.source: All objects, including the camera, are positioned and oriented in this space.
segment.target: All objects, including the camera, are positioned and oriented in this space.

segment.source: In the sample game, the camera's position along with the look vectors (the "look at" vector that points directly into the scene from the camera, and the "look up" vector that is upwards perpendicular to it) define the camera space.
segment.target: In the sample game, the camera's position along with the look vectors (the "look at" vector that points directly into the scene from the camera, and the "look up" vector that is upwards perpendicular to it) define the camera space.

segment.source: The projection parameters determine how much of that space is actually visible in the final scene; and the Field of View (FoV), aspect ratio, and clipping planes define the projection transformation.
segment.target: The projection parameters determine how much of that space is actually visible in the final scene; and the Field of View (FoV), aspect ratio, and clipping planes define the projection transformation.

segment.source: A vertex shader does the heavy lifting of converting from the model coordinates to device coordinates with the following algorithm (where V is a vector and M is a matrix):
segment.target: A vertex shader does the heavy lifting of converting from the model coordinates to device coordinates with the following algorithm (where V is a vector and M is a matrix):

segment.source: is a transformation matrix for model coordinates to world coordinates.
segment.target: is a transformation matrix for model coordinates to world coordinates.

segment.source: This is provided by the primitive.
segment.target: This is provided by the primitive.

segment.source: (We'll review this in the section on primitives, here.)
segment.target: (We'll review this in the section on primitives, here.)

segment.source: is a transformation matrix for world coordinates to view coordinates.
segment.target: is a transformation matrix for world coordinates to view coordinates.

segment.source: This is provided by the view matrix of the camera.
segment.target: This is provided by the view matrix of the camera.

segment.source: is a transformation matrix for view coordinates to device coordinates.
segment.target: is a transformation matrix for view coordinates to device coordinates.

segment.source: This is provided by the projection of the camera.
segment.target: This is provided by the projection of the camera.

segment.source: The shader code in VertexShader.hlsl is loaded with these vectors and matrices from the constant buffers, and performs this transformation for every vertex.
segment.target: The shader code in VertexShader.hlsl is loaded with these vectors and matrices from the constant buffers, and performs this transformation for every vertex.

segment.source: The Camera object defines the view and projection matrices.
segment.target: The Camera object defines the view and projection matrices.

segment.source: Let's look at how the sample game declares it.
segment.target: Let's look at how the sample game declares it.

segment.source: There are two 4x4 matrices that define the transformations to the view and projection coordinates, m\_viewMatrix and m\_projectionMatrix.
segment.target: There are two 4x4 matrices that define the transformations to the view and projection coordinates, m\_viewMatrix and m\_projectionMatrix.

segment.source: (For stereo projection, you use two projection matrices: one for each eye's view.) They are calculated with these two methods, respectively:
segment.target: (For stereo projection, you use two projection matrices: one for each eye's view.) They are calculated with these two methods, respectively:

segment.source: SetViewParams
segment.target: SetViewParams

segment.source: SetProjParams
segment.target: SetProjParams

segment.source: The code for these two methods looks like this:
segment.target: The code for these two methods looks like this:

segment.source: We get the resulting view and projection data by calling the View and Projection methods, respectively, on the Camera object.
segment.target: We get the resulting view and projection data by calling the View and Projection methods, respectively, on the Camera object.

segment.source: These calls occur in the next step we review, the GameRenderer::Render method called in the game loop.
segment.target: These calls occur in the next step we review, the GameRenderer::Render method called in the game loop.

segment.source: Now, let's look at how the game creates the framework to draw our game graphics using the camera.
segment.target: Now, let's look at how the game creates the framework to draw our game graphics using the camera.

segment.source: This includes defining the primitives that comprise the game world and its elements.
segment.target: This includes defining the primitives that comprise the game world and its elements.

segment.source: Defining the primitives
segment.target: Defining the primitives

segment.source: In the game sample code, we define and implement the primitives in two base classes and the corresponding specializations for each primitive type.
segment.target: In the game sample code, we define and implement the primitives in two base classes and the corresponding specializations for each primitive type.

segment.source: MeshObject.h/.cpp defines the base class for all mesh objects.
segment.target: MeshObject.h/.cpp defines the base class for all mesh objects.

segment.source: The SphereMesh.h/.cpp, CylinderMesh.h/.cpp, FaceMesh.h/.cpp, and WorldMesh.h/.cpp files contain the code that populates the constant buffers for each primitive with the vertex and vertex normal data that defines the primitive's geometry.
segment.target: The SphereMesh.h/.cpp, CylinderMesh.h/.cpp, FaceMesh.h/.cpp, and WorldMesh.h/.cpp files contain the code that populates the constant buffers for each primitive with the vertex and vertex normal data that defines the primitive's geometry.

segment.source: These code files are a good place to start if you're looking to understand how to create Direct3D primitives in your own game app, but we won't cover them here as it's too specific to this game's implementation.
segment.target: These code files are a good place to start if you're looking to understand how to create Direct3D primitives in your own game app, but we won't cover them here as it's too specific to this game's implementation.

segment.source: For now, we assume that the vertex buffers for each primitive have been populated, and look at how the game sample handles those buffers to update the game itself.
segment.target: For now, we assume that the vertex buffers for each primitive have been populated, and look at how the game sample handles those buffers to update the game itself.

segment.source: The base class for objects that represent the primitives from the perspective of the game is defined in GameObject.h./.cpp.
segment.target: The base class for objects that represent the primitives from the perspective of the game is defined in GameObject.h./.cpp.

segment.source: This class, GameObject, defines the fields and methods for the common behaviors across all primitives.
segment.target: This class, GameObject, defines the fields and methods for the common behaviors across all primitives.

segment.source: Each primitive object type derives from it.
segment.target: Each primitive object type derives from it.

segment.source: Let's look at how it's defined:
segment.target: Let's look at how it's defined:

segment.source: Most of the fields contain data about the state, visual properties, or position of the primitive in the game world.
segment.target: Most of the fields contain data about the state, visual properties, or position of the primitive in the game world.

segment.source: There are a few methods in particular that are necessary in most games:
segment.target: There are a few methods in particular that are necessary in most games:

segment.source: Mesh.
segment.target: Mesh.

segment.source: Gets the mesh geometry for the primitive, which is stored in m\_mesh.
segment.target: Gets the mesh geometry for the primitive, which is stored in m\_mesh.

segment.source: This geometry is defined in MeshObject.h/.cpp.
segment.target: This geometry is defined in MeshObject.h/.cpp.

segment.source: IsTouching.
segment.target: IsTouching.

segment.source: This method determines if the primitive is within a specific distance of a point, and returns the point on the surface closest to the point and the normal to the surface of the object at that point.
segment.target: This method determines if the primitive is within a specific distance of a point, and returns the point on the surface closest to the point and the normal to the surface of the object at that point.

segment.source: Because the sample is only concerned with ammo-primitive collisions, this is enough for the game's dynamics.
segment.target: Because the sample is only concerned with ammo-primitive collisions, this is enough for the game's dynamics.

segment.source: It is not a general purpose primitive-primitive intersection function, although it could be used as the basis for one.
segment.target: It is not a general purpose primitive-primitive intersection function, although it could be used as the basis for one.

segment.source: AnimatePosition.
segment.target: AnimatePosition.

segment.source: Updates the movement and animation for the primitive.
segment.target: Updates the movement and animation for the primitive.

segment.source: UpdatePosition.
segment.target: UpdatePosition.

segment.source: Updates the position of the object in the world coordinate space.
segment.target: Updates the position of the object in the world coordinate space.

segment.source: Render.
segment.target: Render.

segment.source: Puts the material properties of the primitive into the primitive constant buffer and then renders (draws) the primitive geometry using the device context.
segment.target: Puts the material properties of the primitive into the primitive constant buffer and then renders (draws) the primitive geometry using the device context.

segment.source: It's a good practice to create a base object type that defines the minimum set of methods for a primitive because most games have a very large number of primitives, and the code can quickly become difficult to manage.
segment.target: It's a good practice to create a base object type that defines the minimum set of methods for a primitive because most games have a very large number of primitives, and the code can quickly become difficult to manage.

segment.source: It also simplifies game code when the update loop can treat the primitives polymorphically, letting the objects themselves define their own update and rendering behaviors.
segment.target: It also simplifies game code when the update loop can treat the primitives polymorphically, letting the objects themselves define their own update and rendering behaviors.

segment.source: Let's look at the basic rendering of a primitive in the game sample.
segment.target: Let's look at the basic rendering of a primitive in the game sample.

segment.source: Rendering the primitives
segment.target: Rendering the primitives

segment.source: The primitives in the game sample use the base Render method implemented on the parent GameObject class, as here:
segment.target: The primitives in the game sample use the base Render method implemented on the parent GameObject class, as here:

segment.source: The GameObject::Render method updates the primitive constant buffer with the data specific to a given primitive.
segment.target: The GameObject::Render method updates the primitive constant buffer with the data specific to a given primitive.

segment.source: The game uses multiple constant buffers, but only needs to update these buffers one time per primitive.
segment.target: The game uses multiple constant buffers, but only needs to update these buffers one time per primitive.

segment.source: Think of the constant buffers as input to the shaders that run for each primitive.
segment.target: Think of the constant buffers as input to the shaders that run for each primitive.

segment.source: Some data is static (m\_constantBufferNeverChanges); some data is constant over the frame (m\_constantBufferChangesEveryFrame), like the position of the camera; and some data is specific to the primitive, like its color and textures (m\_constantBufferChangesEveryPrim).
segment.target: Some data is static (m\_constantBufferNeverChanges); some data is constant over the frame (m\_constantBufferChangesEveryFrame), like the position of the camera; and some data is specific to the primitive, like its color and textures (m\_constantBufferChangesEveryPrim).

segment.source: The game renderer separates these inputs into different constant buffers to optimize the memory bandwidth that the CPU and GPU use.
segment.target: The game renderer separates these inputs into different constant buffers to optimize the memory bandwidth that the CPU and GPU use.

segment.source: This approach also helps to minimize the amount of data the GPU needs to keep track of.
segment.target: This approach also helps to minimize the amount of data the GPU needs to keep track of.

segment.source: Remember, the GPU has a big queue of commands, and each time the game calls Draw, that command is queued along with the data associated with it.
segment.target: Remember, the GPU has a big queue of commands, and each time the game calls Draw, that command is queued along with the data associated with it.

segment.source: When the game updates the primitive constant buffer and issues the next Draw command, the graphics driver adds this next command and the associated data to the queue.
segment.target: When the game updates the primitive constant buffer and issues the next Draw command, the graphics driver adds this next command and the associated data to the queue.

segment.source: If the game draws 100 primitives, it could potentially have 100 copies of the constant buffer data in the queue.
segment.target: If the game draws 100 primitives, it could potentially have 100 copies of the constant buffer data in the queue.

segment.source: We want to minimize the amount of data the game is sending to the GPU, so the game uses a separate primitive constant buffer that only contains the updates for each primitive.
segment.target: We want to minimize the amount of data the game is sending to the GPU, so the game uses a separate primitive constant buffer that only contains the updates for each primitive.

segment.source: If a collision (a hit) is detected, GameObject::Render checks the current context, which indicates whether the target has been hit by an ammo sphere.
segment.target: If a collision (a hit) is detected, GameObject::Render checks the current context, which indicates whether the target has been hit by an ammo sphere.

segment.source: If the target has been hit, this method applies a hit material, which reverses the colors of the rings of the target to indicate a successful hit to the player.
segment.target: If the target has been hit, this method applies a hit material, which reverses the colors of the rings of the target to indicate a successful hit to the player.

segment.source: Otherwise, it applies the default material with the same method.
segment.target: Otherwise, it applies the default material with the same method.

segment.source: In both cases, it sets the material by calling Material::RenderSetup, which sets the appropriate constants into the constant buffer.
segment.target: In both cases, it sets the material by calling Material::RenderSetup, which sets the appropriate constants into the constant buffer.

segment.source: Then, it calls ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShaderResources to set the corresponding texture resource for the pixel shader, and ID3D11DeviceContext::VSSetShader and ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShader to set the vertex shader and pixel shader objects themselves, respectively.
segment.target: Then, it calls ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShaderResources to set the corresponding texture resource for the pixel shader, and ID3D11DeviceContext::VSSetShader and ID3D11DeviceContext::PSSetShader to set the vertex shader and pixel shader objects themselves, respectively.

segment.source: Here's how Material::RenderSetup configures the constant buffers and assigns the shader resources.
segment.target: Here's how Material::RenderSetup configures the constant buffers and assigns the shader resources.

segment.source: Again, note that the constant buffer is the one used for updating changes to primitives, specifically.
segment.target: Again, note that the constant buffer is the one used for updating changes to primitives, specifically.

segment.source: Note The Material class is defined in Material.h/.cpp.
segment.target: Note The Material class is defined in Material.h/.cpp.

segment.source: Finally, the PrimObject::Render calls the Render method for the underlying MeshObject object.
segment.target: Finally, the PrimObject::Render calls the Render method for the underlying MeshObject object.

segment.source: Now, the game sample’s MeshObject::Render method queues the drawing command to execute the shaders on the GPU using the current scene state.
segment.target: Now, the game sample’s MeshObject::Render method queues the drawing command to execute the shaders on the GPU using the current scene state.

segment.source: The vertex shader converts the geometry (vertices) from model coordinates into device (world) coordinates, taking into account where the camera is and the perspective transformation.
segment.target: The vertex shader converts the geometry (vertices) from model coordinates into device (world) coordinates, taking into account where the camera is and the perspective transformation.

segment.source: Lastly, the pixel shaders render the transformed triangles into the back buffer using the texture set above.
segment.target: Lastly, the pixel shaders render the transformed triangles into the back buffer using the texture set above.

segment.source: This happens on the actual rendering process!
segment.target: This happens on the actual rendering process!

segment.source: Creating the vertex and pixel shaders
segment.target: Creating the vertex and pixel shaders

segment.source: At this point, the game sample has defined the primitives to draw and the constant buffers that define their rendering.
segment.target: At this point, the game sample has defined the primitives to draw and the constant buffers that define their rendering.

segment.source: These constant buffers serve as the sets of parameters to the shaders that run on the graphics device.
segment.target: These constant buffers serve as the sets of parameters to the shaders that run on the graphics device.

segment.source: These shader programs come in two types:
segment.target: These shader programs come in two types:

segment.source: Vertex shaders perform per-vertex operations, such as vertex transformations and lighting.
segment.target: Vertex shaders perform per-vertex operations, such as vertex transformations and lighting.

segment.source: Pixel (or fragment) shaders perform per-pixel operations, such as texturing and per-pixel lighting.
segment.target: Pixel (or fragment) shaders perform per-pixel operations, such as texturing and per-pixel lighting.

segment.source: They can also be used to perform post-processing effects on bitmaps, such as the final render target.
segment.target: They can also be used to perform post-processing effects on bitmaps, such as the final render target.

segment.source: The shader code is defined using High-Level Shader Language (HLSL), which, in Direct3D 11, is compiled from a program created with a C-like syntax.
segment.target: The shader code is defined using High-Level Shader Language (HLSL), which, in Direct3D 11, is compiled from a program created with a C-like syntax.

segment.source: (The complete syntax can be found here.) The two principal shaders for the sample game are defined in PixelShader.hlsl and VertexShader.hlsl.
segment.target: (The complete syntax can be found here.) The two principal shaders for the sample game are defined in PixelShader.hlsl and VertexShader.hlsl.

segment.source: (There are also two "low power" shaders defined for low power devices: PixelShaderFlat.hlsl and VertexShaderFlat.hlsl.
segment.target: (There are also two "low power" shaders defined for low power devices: PixelShaderFlat.hlsl and VertexShaderFlat.hlsl.

segment.source: These two shaders provide reduced effects, such as a lack of specular highlights on textures surfaces.) FInally, there is an .hlsli file that contains the format of the constant buffers, ConstantBuffers.hlsli.
segment.target: These two shaders provide reduced effects, such as a lack of specular highlights on textures surfaces.) FInally, there is an .hlsli file that contains the format of the constant buffers, ConstantBuffers.hlsli.

segment.source: ConstantBuffers.hlsli is defined like this:
segment.target: ConstantBuffers.hlsli is defined like this:

segment.source: VertexShader.hlsl is defined like this:
segment.target: VertexShader.hlsl is defined like this:

segment.source: VertexShader.hlsl
segment.target: VertexShader.hlsl

segment.source: The main function in VertexShader.hlsl performs the vertex transformation sequence we discussed in the camera section.
segment.target: The main function in VertexShader.hlsl performs the vertex transformation sequence we discussed in the camera section.

segment.source: It's run one time per vertex.
segment.target: It's run one time per vertex.

segment.source: The resultant outputs are passed to the pixel shader code for texturing and material effects.
segment.target: The resultant outputs are passed to the pixel shader code for texturing and material effects.

segment.source: PixelShader.hlsl
segment.target: PixelShader.hlsl

segment.source: The main function in PixelShader.hlsl takes the 2-D projections of the triangle surfaces for each primitive in the scene, and computes the color value for each pixel of the visible surfaces based on the textures and effects (in this case, specular lighting) applied to them.
segment.target: The main function in PixelShader.hlsl takes the 2-D projections of the triangle surfaces for each primitive in the scene, and computes the color value for each pixel of the visible surfaces based on the textures and effects (in this case, specular lighting) applied to them.

segment.source: Now, let's bring all these ideas (primitives, camera, and shaders) together, and see how the sample game builds the complete rendering process.
segment.target: Now, let's bring all these ideas (primitives, camera, and shaders) together, and see how the sample game builds the complete rendering process.

segment.source: Rendering the frame for output
segment.target: Rendering the frame for output

segment.source: We briefly discussed this method in Defining the main game object.
segment.target: We briefly discussed this method in Defining the main game object.

segment.source: Now, let's look at it in a little more detail.
segment.target: Now, let's look at it in a little more detail.

segment.source: The game has all the pieces to assemble a view for output: primitives and the rules for their behavior, a camera object to provide the player's view of the game world, and the graphics resources for drawing.
segment.target: The game has all the pieces to assemble a view for output: primitives and the rules for their behavior, a camera object to provide the player's view of the game world, and the graphics resources for drawing.

segment.source: Now, let's look at the process that brings it all together.
segment.target: Now, let's look at the process that brings it all together.

segment.source: If stereo 3D is enabled, set the following rendering process to run two times, one time for each eye.
segment.target: If stereo 3D is enabled, set the following rendering process to run two times, one time for each eye.

segment.source: The whole scene is enclosed in a bounding world volume, so draw every pixel (even those we don’t need) to clear the color planes of the render target.
segment.target: The whole scene is enclosed in a bounding world volume, so draw every pixel (even those we don’t need) to clear the color planes of the render target.

segment.source: Set the depth stencil buffer to the default value.
segment.target: Set the depth stencil buffer to the default value.

segment.source: Update the constant buffer for frame update data by using the camera's view matrix and data.
segment.target: Update the constant buffer for frame update data by using the camera's view matrix and data.

segment.source: Set up the Direct3D context to use the four content buffers that were defined earlier.
segment.target: Set up the Direct3D context to use the four content buffers that were defined earlier.

segment.source: Call the Render method on each primitive object.
segment.target: Call the Render method on each primitive object.

segment.source: This results in a Draw or DrawIndexed call on the context to draw the geometry of that each primitive.
segment.target: This results in a Draw or DrawIndexed call on the context to draw the geometry of that each primitive.

segment.source: Specifically, this Draw call queues commands and data to the GPU, as parameterized by the constant buffer data.
segment.target: Specifically, this Draw call queues commands and data to the GPU, as parameterized by the constant buffer data.

segment.source: Each draw call executes the vertex shader one time per vertex, and then the pixel shader one time for every pixel of each triangle in the primitive.
segment.target: Each draw call executes the vertex shader one time per vertex, and then the pixel shader one time for every pixel of each triangle in the primitive.

segment.source: The textures are part of the state that the pixel shader uses to do the rendering.
segment.target: The textures are part of the state that the pixel shader uses to do the rendering.

segment.source: Draw the HUD and the overlay using the Direct2D context.
segment.target: Draw the HUD and the overlay using the Direct2D context.

segment.source: Call DirectXBase::Present.
segment.target: Call DirectXBase::Present.

segment.source: And the game has updated the display!
segment.target: And the game has updated the display!

segment.source: Altogether, this is the basic process for implementing the graphics framework of a game.
segment.target: Altogether, this is the basic process for implementing the graphics framework of a game.

segment.source: Of course, the larger your game, the more abstractions you must put in place to handle that complexity, such as entire hierarchies of object types and animation behaviors, and more complex methods for loading and managing assets such as meshes and textures.
segment.target: Of course, the larger your game, the more abstractions you must put in place to handle that complexity, such as entire hierarchies of object types and animation behaviors, and more complex methods for loading and managing assets such as meshes and textures.

segment.source: Next steps
segment.target: Next steps

segment.source: Moving forward, let's look at a few important parts of the game sample that we've only discussed in passing: the user interface overlay, the input controls, and the sound.
segment.target: Moving forward, let's look at a few important parts of the game sample that we've only discussed in passing: the user interface overlay, the input controls, and the sound.

segment.source: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: This article is for Windows 10 developers writing Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
